messageBody:
Kent,
Thank you for your explanations. I think they are pretty clear. I will
re-read your paper later on (it can take some time, though) and I will
post my comments here.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kentb" <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> Alex,
>
> The payment collection process is a fairly typical business process:
one a
> quarter (say), the client owes the insurance company $1000. Out goes a
> request, then if no money comes in out go a series of reminders.
When the
> money comes in it has to be matched to the original request. If the
amount
> is wrong, someone needs to figure out how to reconcile the
situation. The
> business logic in such situations can be incredibly complicated,
primarily
> because of the wide range of scenarios that happen in real life.
Part of the
> challenge is automating as much processing as possible, but balance
this by
> asking for manual assistance any time the business or the
relationship with
> the customer might be put at risk.
>
> "Stability" means how stable the API is that is being tested. An
interface
> that changes daily (not just accretion, but actual changes) probably
> shouldn't have automated tests--they are just a pain.
>
> "Reliability" means how likely the programmer is to make a mistake while
> programming. Code that is dead simple doesn't benefit much from
tests, while
> writing code with lots of logic and interactions can be helped by tests.
>
> Regards,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
>
> _____

> Hi, Kent!
> Your example with Chart API is good. However, your example with
> payment processing is completely nightmare for me. I didn't understand
> what does the application, what client thought and what what problem
> you strike with. I also didn't understand your Stability and
> Reliability aspect. I guess this is because I didn't understand your
> payment processing example.
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups. <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> com, "kentb"
> <kentb@> wrote:
> >
> > All,
> >
> > Last week on succeeding days I encountered two situations, one where
> > system-level tests were valuable and unit tests would have been
> useless and
> > one where the reverse was true. Since simply the level of the tests
> is not
> > sufficient to decide where to test, I thought a bit more about how I
> should
> > decide where to test. I came to three criteria:
> > * The cost of writing and running the test
> > * The stability of the interface the test is, errr..., testing
> > * The reliability of the code satisfying the test
> >
> > I wrote this up in a little paper:
> > www.threeriversinstitute.org/WhereToTest.html. Comments welcome.
> >
> > Kent Beck
> > Three Rivers Institute
